ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more Chinese vocabulary and advanced grammar constructions. I improved my speaking, writing, and reading abilities during class.
Strongly improved my Chinese skills, especially listening and speaking
My Chinese improved in every respect by taking this course. From tones to writing and spoken comprehension, I became a more fluent speaker.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is already very strong. I liked that my section's professor let us write a ~6 short paragraphs in Chinese over the semester instead of 2 longer essays.

Strengths: fast-paced, lots of evaluation. Weaknesses: gets monotonous 

Overall excellent course if you really want to improve your language skills
The course is extremely well organized. Sometimes major projects overlap but Li Laoshi was very understanding and accommodating with due dates.

Strengths: you learn so much
Weaknesses: repetitive
An impressive amount of content, and lots of homework to keep you on task. This strength can also be a weakness, however. With so many assignments, it can be difficult to keep track of.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student who wants to improve their Mandarin level. I especially appreciate that the workload of this course is not too large, and it is generally very consistent; except for ~2 presentations, the workload from one class to the next is almost always exactly the same.
Yes, especially with Ms. Li. She is the best instructor in any subject that I've ever had at Yale.
Absolutely. Take it and your Chinese will get much better
I certainly would, especially after having taken Chinese 150. It builds on the skills youll have already learned in the Fall. The course is truly a natural progression.
Yes, it is an excellent opportunity to sharpen your Mandarin.
